quizzes.question: How many parameters can be accepted by the "alert" function?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The Alert Box[/h1]

JavaScript offers three types of popup boxes, the [b]Alert[/b], [b]Prompt[/b], and [b]Confirm [/b]boxes.

[h2]Alert Box[/h2]
An[b] alert box[/b] is used when you want to ensure that information gets through to the user.
When an alert box pops up, the user must click OK to proceed.
The [b]alert [/b]function takes a single parameter, which is the text displayed in the popup box.
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="js" codeId="682"][b]alert[/b]("Do you really want to leave this page?"); [/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2760" width="100%"]
To display [b]line breaks[/b] within a popup box, use a backslash followed by the character n.[code format="js" codeId="683"]alert("Hello[b]\n[/b]How are you?");[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2761" width="100%"]
[note]Be careful when using alert boxes, as the user can continue using the page only after clicking OK.[/note]

[h1]Prompt Box[/h1]

A [b]prompt box[/b] is often used to have the user input a value before entering a page.
When a prompt box pops up, the user will have to click either OK or Cancel to proceed after entering the input value.
If the user clicks OK, the box[b] returns the input value[/b]. If the user clicks Cancel, the box returns [b]null[/b].

The [b]prompt()[/b] method takes [b]two parameters[/b]. 
- The first is the label, which you want to display in the text box.
- The second is a default string to display in the text box (optional).

[b]Example:[/b] [code format="js" codeId="684"]var user = prompt("Please enter your name");
alert(user);[/code]
[b]The prompt appears as: [/b][img id="2762" width="100%"]
